instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01418: What is 820-01418? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01418</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> keeps shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,

I have that board that was liquid damaged.
I have already replaced <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> as it was shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.
The chip is an SIC532 but showing up as SIC535CD on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> schematics (pretty close to the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01418</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)

Board was then working fine. I could use it for a day or so.
Then again, same short, same dead IC.

After replacing it again, board would work again.
I did replace that chip 3 times already (and it's no fun cause it seats between CPU and GPU)
So my question is: what can cause that IC to die over and over again?

Could it be the CPU draining to much amperage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01418</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> keeps shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have 14 ohms to ground on <SIGNAL>PVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> (same value with another working board)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01418</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> keeps shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01418</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> keeps shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks! I'll try that on Monday.

Can I please ask you how you got to that conclusion please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01418</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> keeps shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I cannot assure that is your problem.
But bootstrap circuit can damage high-side MOSFET in time; if doesn't assure correct voltage Vgs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01418</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> keeps shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You were very close. It was <RESISTOR>R7375</RESISTOR> that was off value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01418</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> keeps shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I supposed you have correct power at <CHIP>U7370</CHIP>.
Higher value on <RESISTOR>R7375</RESISTOR> will impede correct working, of course.
